  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
It’s the first official day of summer and the
  Environmental Protection Agency has its eyes on the skies. Is the air
  you’re breathing clean enough? Research has shown that high ozone
  levels can have lethal consequences, so the EPA is proposing tightening smog
  standards. Wyatt Andrews will have the story tonight.
 
Some of those most affected by high ozone levels are
  the country's children — especially those who live close to major
  highways. John Blackstone will take us inside a children's hospital in San Francisco to look at the impact of living in one of America's
  smoggiest cities.
 
Turning our attention to Iraq,
  the U.S.
  military announced the deaths of 14 soldiers and Marines over the past two
  days. Five soldiers were killed in one roadside bomb attack in northeastern Baghdad. David Martin
  will have the latest on what the Pentagon says about how the surge is
  progressing.
 
There’s a new experimental treatment for
  Parkinson’s that shows promise for some patients. Michelle Miller will
  have the details.
 
Like Michael Moore’s other controversial
  films, “Sicko” drew a huge crowd at its premiere and is getting
  lots of attention from the entertainment media, the health care industry and
  even from Capitol Hill. Will the film’s box-office draw also have some
  affect on the 2008 ballot box? Jeff Greenfield will take a look.
 
To wrap up our broadcast, Cynthia Bowers will take a
  look at the receding shorelines of the largest freshwater lake in the world
  – Lake Superior. Over the past decade
  the lake’s water level has dropped 2 ½ feet – that’s 16
  trillion gallons of water. Where has it gone? We’ll tell you tonight.
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
